description: Jacobsthal function A048669 applied to the product of the first n primes (A002110).
comments: Pintz showed that j(x#) >=  (2e^gamma + o(1)) x log x log log log x / (log log x)^2 and hence a(n) >= (2e^gamma + o(1)) n log^2 n log log log n / (log log n)^2 by the Prime Number Theorem. - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Sep 08 2012Jacobsthal conjectured that a(n) >= j(k) := A048669(k) for any k with n prime factors, which would make this the RECORDS transform of A048669. Hajdu & Saradha disprove the conjecture, showing that this fails for n = 24 where j(76964283982898776138308824190) = 236 > 234 = a(24). - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Sep 08 2012
references: L. E. Dickson, History of the Theory of Numbers, Vol. 1, p. 439, Chelsea, 1952.
L. Hajdu and N. Saradha, Disproof of a conjecture of Jacobsthal, Math. Comp. 81 (2012), pp. 2461-2471.
János Pintz, Very large gaps between consecutive primes, Journal of Number Theory 63 (1997), pp. 286-301.
links: Fintan Costello and Paul Watts, An upper bound on Jacobsthal's function (2012).
Thomas R. Hagedorn, Computation of Jacobsthal's function h(n) for n < 50, Math. Comp. 78 (2009) 1073-1087. doi:10.1090/S0025-5718-08-02166-2
H. Iwaniec, On the error term in the linear sieve, Acta. Arith. 19 (1971), pp. 1-30.
formula: a(n) = A058989(n) + 1.a(n) << n^2 log^2 n, see Iwaniec. - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Sep 08 2012a(n) >= (2e^gamma + o(1)) n log^2 n log log log n / (log log n)^2, see Pintz.
mathematica: (* This program is not suitable to compute more than a few terms *) primorial[n_] := Product[Prime[k], {k, 1, n}]; j[n_] := Module[{L = 1, m = 1}, For[k = 2, k <= n + 1, k++, If[GCD[k, n] == 1, If[L + m < k, m = k - L]; L = k]]; m]; a[n_] := a[n] = j[primorial[n]]; Table[Print["a(", n, ") = ", a[n]]; a[n], {n, 1, 10}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Sep 27 2013, after M. F. Hasler *)
author: Jan Kristian Haugland (jankrihau(AT)hotmail.com)
extensions: Terms a(25) onwards from Tom Hagedorn (hagedorn(AT)tcnj.edu), Feb 21 2007
